intro: Cymopterus purpureus var. jonesii, commonly known as the purple globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its globular, fuzzy seed pods and showy purple to pink flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in sagebrush steppe and grassland habitats. It has a sprawling growth habit with branched stems and lance-shaped leaves. The species is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes mallows and cotton, and is known for its ecological importance to pollinators.
